awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Computational-Experimental Approach to Three-dimensional Fracture in Polymer-Ceramic Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
Composite materials are used in spacecrafts, aircrafts, automobiles, and naval vessels for their unique property to provide high strength- and stiffness-to-weight ratios. They are also used in bioengineering and electronic devices; and concrete is a composite that is one of the most widely used materials today. Understanding their behavior is important to advance the design of these materials, as measures taken to further strengthen or stiffen them can sometimes yield counterintuitive or even counterproductive results. This award supports fundamental research on understanding the material properties of composites by examining the three-dimensional mechanics and failure evolution on the microstructural level. An integrated combination of experiments and simulations will be used to study their behavior, with a focus on polymer-ceramic composites. This project will answer fundamental questions about the competing mechanisms on the microscale that lead to the counterintuitive relations between microstructure and resulting composite properties. The new knowledge and tools will lead to advances in the design of composites, and significantly impact the broad range of applications in which these materials are used, thereby impacting national health, prosperity, and welfare; and securing the national defense. The outreach and educational activities in this project will broaden the participation of undergraduate and graduate students, particularly women and from other underrepresented groups, in STEM subjects through research in the PIs' labs. The outreach activities with visiting students from Africa also intends to inspire interest of African-American students in STEM subjects.

A new computational approach called the continua-discontinua particle method (CDPM) is proposed which combines the strengths of traditional continuum-based methods in fundamental mechanics and mathematically grounded principles, with the strengths of discrete methods in simulating arbitrary complex three-dimensional fracture. The method allows the transition under failure from a meshfree particle discretization based on continuum mechanics, to that of a discrete fracture network similar to discrete particle methods. An approach using micro X-ray computed tomography (micro-CT) and an in-situ mechanical tester is proposed, which yields 3D full-field mechanical measurements. Other material characterization methods, such as tensile testing, nanoindentation, and scanning electron microscopy will also be employed to compliment the in-situ experiments. The experiments and simulations will be closely integrated to both formulate and validate the numerical models for prediction of composite stiffness, strength, and toughness of polymer-ceramic composites with varying filler morphology, as well as illuminate the underlying causes of the structure-property relationships in these materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project sets out to develop an integrated computational and experimental approach for the study of the complex fracture behavior of particulate polymer-ceramic composites so that salient design of these composites can be made. In this project, a few breakthroughs were made in the computational techniques and experimental methods, respectively and the two aspects were integrated seamlessly. (1) Fracture mechanics experiment coupled with micro-CT was developed to study the 3D fracture behaviors inside the composites. (2) Several numerical methods, including meshfree immersed composite methods, multi-scale reduced-order methodology, and support vector machine (SVM) guided image-based model discretization, were developed to convert the micro-CT images into computational models with reduced complexity and enhanced accuracy. (3) The experimentally measured mechanical properties, including the elastic moduli of the matrix and the reinforcement, as well as the interfacial fracture toughness, were incorporated into the numerical models to further improve the fidelity of the models. (4) Several numerical algorithms were developed to model the damage and fracture in composites, such as the neural network enriched reproducing kernel particle method (NN-RKPM). (5) The validity of the models was assured by comparing the load-displacement curves and the fracture evolution behaviors obtained from the experiments and the simulations. Compared with the existing state-of-the-art, the in situ experimental method developed in this project can observe failure processes as they occur rather than ex situ observations which can only infer the processes after-the-fact. The computational method developed in this project allows effective simulation of fracture evolution in composites, overcoming the difficulties in using discrete approaches in representing continuum behavior, as well as limitations in continuum approaches in simulating three-dimensional fracture. The comprehensive framework allows for improved numerical and experimental investigations of 3D fracture mechanics in composite materials, by providing metrics for the entire process along with associated state and field variables.

 

Broader Impact: This results from project show that interfacial strength between the reinforcement phase and the matrix are crucial for the fracture behaviors of the particulate polymer-ceramic composites. The stress transfer through the interface governs the competing and coupling mechanisms on the microscale that lead to counterintuitive relations between microstructure and resulting macroscale properties. The new experimental methods and computational methods developed in this project can be used for the research community on composite materials for advancement in the design of composites, and are suitable for a broad range civilian and defense applications, thereby impacting national health, prosperity, and welfare; and securing the national defense. The outreach and educational activities in this project broadened the participation of undergraduate and graduate students, particularly women and other underrepresented groups, in STEM subjects. This project provided education and training opportunities for two postdoctoral researchers, six Ph.D. students, one master’s student and six undergraduate students. Five of them are females. One of the above-mentioned post-docs and one of the Ph.D. students are now faculty members in universities. All six undergraduate students went on to pursue further education in graduate schools.

 

Products: The research team has published ten peer-reviewed journal papers and one conference proceeding paper from this award. One more journal papers and one more conference paper are currently under review. The topics of these papers include the development of new experimental methods and the development of new computational methods for the study of fracture in polymer-ceramic composite materials. The incorporation of experimental and computational works is also presented in these papers. Some of journals focus on computational mechanics and some focus on materials science and engineering. This award also resulted in multiple conference proceedings, presentations including invited talks in conferences, and lectures. 

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Jing Du
